posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My mother seemed to realize early on thatt baking turkey was a clusterfuck. Unless you go full Alton Brown or have a gigantic pressure cooker you end up with overcooked wings and legs and either undercooked breast/thigh or dry as fuck breast.

A busy mother at Christmas can't go all scientific babysitting a goddamn dead bird for 3 hours. SO instead she always bought just big meaty gigantic turkey wings. Dozens of them. She'd roast them with bacon and orange juice and she'd feed like 20 of us every single Christmas and nobody ever needed gravy.

Never seen turkey wings served anywhere ever in life, just at my parents' house on Christmas.

posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

Ham is incredible, and it reminds me of my first venture to the Honeybaked Ham store which was on 12/15/2022.
I had a coupon and thought I would give them a try. I went in the store and a very nice employee, Megan, asked if she could help me. I showed her my coupon and said this was my first time there. I asked for suggestions and she said she liked the roasted turkey sandwich. Since ham is right in the name, I said I think I would try their classic ham sandwich with a side of Bacon Broccolli. I didn't take a picture of the items, as I forgot and I was hungry. The classic ham sandwich came on a croissant and it was very, very good. The Bacon Broccolli was also very good.
On my receipt there was a survey. If I completed the survey I would get a code for a bogo sandwich. So of course I did the survey. Then today I went back to the store. Megan was there, as was the owner. I decided to try the turkey and got 2 of the roasted turkey sandwiches. One for me and one for my hubby. These came on a long roll and were just as good as the ham sandwich I had the day before.
The owner rang me up but didn't know how to enter my phone number so I would receive “piggy points” for my purchase. Megan came over and showed him how to do it. I said to him “You're the owner and you don't know how to do that?” To which he responded he's usually in the back and that the program was new. I asked if Megan was going to make my sandwiches and he joked about me not trusting his sandwich-making abilities. I said, well you didn't know how to give me points. He said yes, Megan would be making my sandwiches. I liked that he could take a joke.
If you are looking for a great ham or turkey sandwich, I suggest giving Honeybaked Ham a try. I know I will be going back there again!!

From Left to right, going to be rating them overall from 1-10 even though they are different types of milk. Going to be rating the strength of the coffee taste from 0 (no taste) to 10 (unbearable) according to my taste, I like pretty strong coffee.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
mascarpone cream for panettone
4 egg yolks
120g sugar
30g water
500g mascarpone, +-100g depending on the desired consistency

mix the yolks with a stand mixer until they become airy
heat the sugar and water, remove when the water's evaporated and the sugar reaches 120°C and pour in the yolks as you keep mixing with the stand mixer
when the mixture cools down to about 30°C add the mascarpone 75-100g at a time and keep mixing
refrigerate and eat within 3-4 days

Let me introduce you panettone gastronomico, an antipasto to share with other family members and friends on Christmas Day lunch or New Year's Eve dinner.

It's a big panettone like bread cut into discs and stuffed with cold cuts, spreadable cheese, mayonnaise and shrimps, smoked salmon, basically whatever you like and then when it's cut into slices you get a "column" of different sandwiches.

You can buy industrial ones at the supermarket or one from a bakery, either plain just the bread or stuffed according to your requests or how they make it.

I always ask "mare e monti" which means sea and mountains (seafood and meat/cold cuts).

1) What are the rules of panettone?

2) This % you speak about, should it be based on flour or on total dough weight?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697726
1) here the official rules from the chamber of commerce of Milano: https://www.milomb.camcom.it/upload/file/1335/667500/FILENAME/disciplinare_panettone_artigianale_2006.pdf

2) total dough weight

>Il Panettone Tipico della Tradizione Artigiana Milanese deve contenere:
>• non meno del 20% in peso sul prodotto di uvetta sultanina, scorze di
arancia candite e cedro candito sull’impasto (calibro minimo 8 x 8)
>• non meno del 10% in peso di materia grassa butirrica sull’impasto.

Traditional artisanal Milanese Panettone has to have not less that 20% of the dough weight composed by sultana raisins and candied fruit.

Also not less than 10% of the total weight of the dough has to be butter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697669
Also, another thing I noticed by reading again the ingredients label is that it lists EGG YOLKS and it’s a very good thing because that’s how it should be made and how they do for high quality panettone.

To keep the costs lower and suitable for the great distribution, industrial producers use whole eggs because it’s cheaper and adds weight to the dough, also the final panettone dough won’t looks as yellow as an artisanal panettone.

TL;DR your panettone is still mass produced but of a higher quality. Nice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18705388
It depends, proofing times are another variable and most artisanal panettone has up to 3 days proofing, some even 4.
Bakeries can even make their own candied fruit, at least the citrus and other fruit too (sultanas are often Australian), they use expensive butter and also have a limited production vs mass produced 'tone.

Ideally, the industrial panettone follows the same procedures of artisanal panettone but most of the work is being done by machines, see:

https://youtu.be/6tYArQm8kpU

The main difference is the ingredients and the proofing times because ideally an industrial panettone made with high quality products with the same proofing times with controlled humidity should lead to a similar result of an artisanal one, but the latter will always be superior because of the highly specialized mother yeast bakeries uses since decades, also they have their ovens (many bakeries have historical super old giant ovens).

It's simply anti economic making a high quality industrial panettone because it will slower the production, therefore mid tier panettone is what you're looking for if you want that thing which combines automation + some artisanal bits and ingredients.

In my non-controlled experiments in bread-making, adding FAT to doughs seems to inhibit the yeast the most. I haven't noticed any effect from more or less salt, although I am trying to be a bit gentle with the salt, mainly because i find commercial goods to be sometimes (often actually) over-salted.

I added a good bit of maple syrup to this batch of dough, and I got a great initial rise in the fridge - the dough is pressing firmly against the plastic wrap

I used a small amount of dried yeast (1/2 tsp maybe) proofed in milk, mixed with ~ 2 cups of sourdough starter, my goal is to make a sourdough bread that isn't too sour, and I added eggs because I want a bit of richness.

My last batch was all-sourdough (no commercial yeast), and it did not rise at all, although my starter perhaps was underfed. A batch before that was all commercial yeast (and a lot of it) and tasted inedibly like alcohol.

>>18706635
It's common knowledge among bakers that sweet doughs take a lot longer to rise because sugar is hygroscopic, which means it's attracted to water, which is something yeast needs to reproduce. This is such a problem for bakers that there are some types of yeast specifically marketed towards sweet doughs. It's one of the reasons why panettone takes a lot of time to rise, even if you make it with commercial yeast.

A common rule to know if your dough can be considered "sweet" and thusly affected by this is to see how much is your sugar percentage in relation to your total flour. If it's more than 10%, it's a sweet dough.

Maple syrup is made out of roughly 60% sugar, which means if you added 100 g of it, you'd actually only added 60 g of actual sugar and 40% it's water.

posts.com:
Protip:
food flavors are basically just flavor chords. for the same reason your brain decides that musical chords sound good together when either notes or higher harmonics overlap a lot, ingredients with a lot of overlap in flavor chemicals tend to taste good together.

if you know from a recipe that foods A and B go well together, and from a different recipe that B and C go well together, there's a decent chance A and C can be mixed together well too. swapping out a single ingredient within similar triplets tends to work even better.

also, much like how in music a key change can be made more tolerable by bridging the transition with a chord progression that emphasizes a chord that the two keys have in common, two different foods that normally don't taste good together can sometimes be mixed successfully with the addition of a third ingredient that works well with each individually and bridges the gap

all my cooking these days is basically just using these rules to throw random stuff together. sometimes i have completely random stuff in my fridge/pantry and i just work out what should work well from a mix of known recipes and simple logic. i continually surprise myself with food that doesn't seem like it should taste good that winds up massively exceeding my expectations.

here's a paper on the subject:
https://www.nature.com/articles/srep00196

Yes, there are. Try German Zwiebelkuchen (onion cake).

500g flour
500g onions
400g sour cream
275ml cold water
50g butter
3 eggs
1 tbsp butter
1tsp salt
1/2 tsp caraway
pepper

For instruction go here and use google translate, I cant translate and type up all that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cake salé. It’s a French savory salted cake with caramelized onion, shredded parmesan or gruyere, ham, peppers, etc. It’s not bread exactly since there’s no yeast, the leavening agent is baking powder. If you wanted to take it a step further you could make an icing with chicken jus and butter or maybe use schmalz.

Cake is a batter instead of a dough so if you pour it instead of knead it you’re probably making cake. If you poured pannekoek batter into a pan with bacon and cheese you’d have a cake.

If you're trying to monetize them they do need to reach a certain standard. People pay for cookies for things like weddings, birthdays, and baby showers so you would need to make products that appeal to this crowd. Royal icing uses a very small amount of corn syrup to give a gloss and it doesn't particularly make it more unhealthy considering the end product mostly consists of sugar, butter, and flour. You can make great cookies that don't have icing of course but they aren't going to have as much of a visual wow factor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697095
They have the thickest cladding of all the clad cookware. The industry 5 is the second thickest rim to rim cladding, only behind their own proline series. Their atlantis 7 series has the most even heating bottoms due to having the thickest bottom cladding of all cookware, but no rim to rim cladding. The problem, as with a lot of cookware, is their handle ergonomics kind of suck. The part of the handle closest to the pan is the thinnest, which makes it uncomfortable when you inevitably choke up on the handle to counteract the leverage on your wrist. Currently, the best overall cookware in my humble opinion is the Hestan Thomas Keller cookware. Their handles are by far the best out of all the clad cookwares, wide and thick where it counts. Their rim to rim cladding is a bit thicker than all-clad's, but not as thick as demeyere. But the rims are sealed so there no chance of the cladding separating over time. And the universal lids are far better than traditional ones. I'm surprised that more companies aren't making them. They're expensive though. Par for the course for all cookware that isn't some chink mystery metal special.
For nonstick I prefer a well seasoned carbon steel pan. A wok and cast iron skillet work well too. These are rather simple and straightforward

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I couldn't tell you. I really just know that these techniques exist. I've never been much of a baker, only used a mixer in the past. I don't own a stand mixer currently so a "no-knead" bread makes sense for my situation. But it can take HOURS for gluten development, I'd probably just end up hand-kneading rather than waiting a day. I believe babish, and probably a few other foodtubers have put out semi-scientific reviews on the different techniques but if you have the tools, the ingredients, and the time, (and maybe some friends to give the extra bread to), I'd suggest trying for yourself. Their reviews will be subjective anyway. As far as I can tell, it's just the gluten development technique that is different, same recipe otherwise.

This depends heavily on the person: if you keep an eye out for a sweet deal on a bread machine on craigslist or FB Marketplace, say, that may actually be worth getting, because you can (if you're this kind of person) get into a habit of home-making your bread for everything, like every week. That will then get your expectations raised on baked goods in general such that maybe next time you reconsider buying a pre-made pastry, and decide spontaneously to attempt it yourself, or that next week you want to make a more elaborate type of bread, which the machine cannot do, and the extra effort will seem worth it because you know that it's a step up from what's already a higher bar.

(This as opposed to where I'm at with baking, where I'm lazy with steps and only doing very basic shit because any shit I throw together is a couple tiers better than the grocery store pastries I eat most of the time).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Don't knock it til you've tried it, it's a great satisfying drink to warm up to in the cold, a bit like a hot chocolate but savoury (and lighter, a cup of Bovril is only like 20 calories). Bovril comes in the form of a really viscous black paste that looks identical to marmite, and some people spread it on toast as well as dissolving it in water.

That being said, as an English Bovril enjoyer I can say that most people here don't like it and think the idea of a "beefy drink" is probably just as weird as Americans think it is. I think Bovril is more of an old fashioned thing, though it's still a big part of football culture, being drank in the stands in the winter. The biggest online forum about Scottish football is called Pie & Bovril.

posts.name: Ham Planet
posts.com:
>>18702074
For me, it's Honeybaked Ham. My first venture to the Honeybaked Ham store was on 12/15/2022.
I had a coupon and thought I would give them a try. I went in the store and a very nice employee, Megan, asked if she could help me. I showed her my coupon and said this was my first time there. I asked for suggestions and she said she liked the roasted turkey sandwich. Since ham is right in the name, I said I think I would try their classic ham sandwich with a side of Bacon Broccolli. I didn't take a picture of the items, as I forgot and I was hungry. The classic ham sandwich came on a croissant and it was very, very good. The Bacon Broccolli was also very good.
On my receipt there was a survey. If I completed the survey I would get a code for a bogo sandwich. So of course I did the survey. Then today I went back to the store. Megan was there, as was the owner. I decided to try the turkey and got 2 of the roasted turkey sandwiches. One for me and one for my hubby. These came on a long roll and were just as good as the ham sandwich I had the day before.
The owner rang me up but didn't know how to enter my phone number so I would receive “piggy points” for my purchase. Megan came over and showed him how to do it. I said to him “You're the owner and you don't know how to do that?” To which he responded he's usually in the back and that the program was new. I asked if Megan was going to make my sandwiches and he joked about me not trusting his sandwich-making abilities. I said, well you didn't know how to give me points. He said yes, Megan would be making my sandwiches. I liked that he could take a joke.
If you are looking for a great ham or turkey sandwich, I suggest giving Honeybaked Ham a try. I know I will be going back there again!!

>>18706837
>Heavy metals bioaccumulate, ... If you ate 1oz of Hershey's Special dark every day, you'd reach that threshold in just over a year.
That's ... not what bioaccumulation is. It's the rate of accumulation minus the rate of excretion. Heavy metals, like just about everything humans take in, are excreted, slowly.
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S277241662200050X
Sometimes a healthy policy might set a guideline on maximum lifetime (or occupational) accumulated dose, which is common for workers exposed to radiation or certain chronic hazards, though again I've really only seen that as an occupational guideline and not an everyday human medicine thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18706939
When you go more granular like this your analysis quickly becomes more naive. From the source you just linked:
>normal individuals absorb only about 6% of ingested cadmium
Or you can look in practice. Exposure to cadmium by food has been a major problem before, and the thresholds and susceptibilities are pretty well documented. You can look through any of the connecting literature on the history here:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5596182/#B14
To take a step back so we stop moving these goal posts every which way, it's not saying that at 1000x there's a risk. Compare say the federal guidelines for cadmium, which go into lifetime exposure risk:
>ATSDR: Chronic durational oral minimal risk level (MRL) of 0.1 µg/kg/day of cadmium based on its renal effects. This MRL standard states how much cadmium can be taken in orally chronically without risk of adverse health effects (ATSDR 1999).
>EPA: Food – Reference dose is 1 x 10-3mg/kg/day (ATSDR 1999). Reference dose (Rfd) is an estimate of a daily exposure to the general population (including sensitive subgroups) that is likely to be without appreciable risk of deleterious effects during a lifetime (IRIS 2006).
https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/csem/cadmium/Safety-Standards.html
Note that the FDA's safety factor on these quantities, depending on the studies they are based on, is likely either 100-fold or 1000-fold (https://www.fda.gov/media/153239/download).

Tldr, this CR article is not anticipating a news story in which thousands of Americans are hospitalized with itai-itai because they eat Lindt chocolates daily. You're not going to be calculating your own exposure risk from your bedroom tonight -- that's done in consultation with a doctor. Normally CR has decent reports, but I don't know what the fuck this shit is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18690765
Scotch is from Scotland. Whisky usually denotes scotch styles but you also have Maker's Mark bourbon and the entire US legal code on alcohol which spells it whisky. Whiskey is an Irish spelling that became more common in the US with the migration, but if you read old letters, people use both interchangeably because spelling wasn't formalized until well after Webster's dictionary came out.

>>18690891
It started using unmalted barley because fuck English taxes and US Prohibition nearly killed the industry of over a thousand distilleries which ushered in the use of column stills. Pot stilled Irish is really good, though not usually as complex or funky as scotch, and shares a lot with American styles that aren't bourbon.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18690765
No e in scotch whisky.
No consistency everywhere else, it is not a protected term.
>Legal destinations for products
You'll find many are not protected, and many that you think are are actually only protected by trade agreement. And you'll commonly see legal loop holes.
Japanese whisky doesn't have to be Japanese. Bourbon doesn't have to be American or corn or any of that shit if it's intended for export.
I have consumed Australian champagne, bourbon, port, sherry, parmesan, cheddar etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18693750
Different stills.
Different cuts.
Barrel char level.
Barrel variation and barrel blending (some distilleries will save all the better barrels for more expensive bottles for example, or some will have less barrels so have a less uniform product ).
Yeast strain.
Chill filtration, colour, dilution.
Blending with older whisky.
Barrel finishes.
Secret disregard of certain rules, especially when it comes to the lattermost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18694715
You try all of the other similar scotches. Including independent bottlings. Then you choose the best value among those. Then it gets discontinued and you start again (or it doesn't).
I'd probably go for the cask strength Smokehead (Caol Ila) over that. Or maybe the 6 isles (mostly Ledaig, cheap) or Compass Box Peat Monster (Mostly Caol Ila, a little cheaper than Laphroaig).

Or you can broaden your horizons a little and go for non Isla peat (like Glenfiddich, Loch Lomond, Benromach, Benriach, Tomintoul, Connemara, etc).
Or go for sherried peat like Longrow Red (or of course indie bottlings of any of your favourite Islays).

Of course have you tried QC or Lore? sherry? cairdeas? 3 oak? etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18705779
It's 2 shelves down from bulleit, usually a 30% price difference. ~$25 vs ~35 depending on regional monopoly. It nails a lot of quintessential bourbon flavors and doesn't skimp on the proof. Not the best but the personal favorite of many along with Old Forester 100 and a few other old names with low prices offering higher proof than the legal minimum.

>>18706028
Red Breast 12 or 16, Mularkey if you can find it in your areas--they do a black barrel irish style that's really good, Green Spot, one of the newer ones like the Irishman. You may have to hit up a few good stores in nicer areas, irish availability is shit, especially when you get into single pot or the newer brands and the old ones that have been revived.

Or take a chance on something local with either an age statement or some assurance that it's old enough to be worth the price and was actually made by the distillery in question. There's good stuff out there that no one knows or cares about because it doesn't say buffalo trace on the bottle and gets you no clout among redditors. Also a lot of shit, but that's why the mixer was invented in 1920.

If you live in a state monopoly, the website may have a good inventory system and save you some trips and phone calls.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18705308
I'v tried that before. Never really carmelizes with the low heat. Instead the (real) maple syrup is in the cure. About 2/3 cup vermont maple syrup, 1/2 cup of maker's mark bourbon, roughly 80 grams of kosher salt, 4 tblsp cracked black pepper, 5.5g pink salt, 1/2 cup warm distilled water. Mix all ingredients except pepper. Inject about 1/2 of cure into meat. Rub meat down with pepper, pressing it into the meat and fat side. Place meat in cacuum (or zipper) bag. Pour in rest of cure. Seal bag. Place in fridge for 7 - 10 days, turning over once a day.
When cured, smoke to 155 - 165F. You can eat this bacon as is because it's already cooked, or you can fry it up like store bought bacon.

Pic is current progress. 127°F.

>stop phone posting old ass data retard
This. But a big contributing factor is the enormous bread subsidies in several MENA countries. Usually despite economic collapse, bread subsidies are the last thing MENA governments will let go of -- and when approaching the IMF for a bailout, it's the first thing they want a timeline in place to phase out.

Egypt in particular had notoriously ridiculous bread subsidies, that in the 1950s were still-ridiculous-but-significantly-less so. The problem is that they set a fixed price on bread that didn't move with inflation, so at the point when Mubarak decided to initiate a gradual reduction (amidst economic crisis, longstanding pressure from domestic economists and the international everybody, and a general sense to modernize) the price of bread (this subsidy only applied specifically to a basic flatbread, btw, not grain in general) was something like 10% of market value. The problem with the gradual phase out was that the first increment was to raise the price of bread to 20% of market value. Now you math geniuses out there will realize Mubarak doubled the price of the staple food of the entire population (poor people obv, and rich people eat it as tortillas or whatnot) overnight. Mass protests threatening revolution ensued and the policy was rolled back within a week. Fast forward to the Arab Spring, and most credible analysts blame almost every revolution in large part or entirely due to bread prices. Cheap bread was a populist measure for dictators to consolidate power in these MENA countries that would later become their greatest liability.

And also it makes people fat.

>>18704249
I don't know of any chinese ground tea that's similar in quality to good matcha. It probably exists but I'd bet its in such small batches it's not worth seeking out. Japanese are more hyperfixated on doing things a certain way than the Chinese.

>for Chinese tea do you need those small 80ml cups?
Do you mean a gaiwan or the actual drinking cup?
You can drink tea out of whatever you like, though more neutral material like porcelain or glass is better. The idea of drinking out of a small cup is to influence the mouth feel and cool it down quicker so you can drink it faster and taste more. Certain cups exist to increase aroma, some focus more on cooling faster, really if you ever get into wanting a kind of cup it'll mostly be for aesthetics. Very few people really get several kinds of cups for different occasions, some people into tasting get smelling cups. I do find myself enjoying the flavor more out of my porcelain 60 ml cups more than my antique western style 6 oz teacups, but I use the 6 oz cup more because I don't have to use a gong dao bei.
>Impossible to make amounts like I'm used to with western teas if I want to go for quality?
eh, I typically get a bit more tea liquor out of gong fu brewing overall than if I used the same amount of leaf to brew western style. But at once? Yeah you're going to get less, but brew times are faster. I guess its more an active effort to taste tea than just western style drinking. I still mostly brew red tea in western style because the quality increase in gong fu is negligible unless I'm really in the mood for trying to find different notes.
Japanese tea is the annoying one. you only get 3, maybe 4, extractions and it's a higher leaf to water ratio than chinese, so it ends up costing more money for less tea. But japanese green tea is stupidly harsh on the stomach anyways so maybe its for the best it's harder to drink a liter of it.

i only use 100ml gaiwans and 120ml for some teas, 200ml is huge imo. i then i drink from a 50ml cup and generally i drink around 1.5L per gongfu session and using 5-7g of tea, its still a bit more than 3-4g of tea for the same amount western brewed but i think its worth it, i usually grandpa brew instead of western brewing if i want a lot of tea though.
>Is their a Chinese tea that compares in class and taste?
Taste no, generally Japanese teas are more savoury while Chinese teas are sweeter, even Chinese green teas taste very different as Japanese greens are processed with steaming while Chinese greens are roasted in a pan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18704336
Chinese tea culture is hyper casual so there's not really anything nearly as classy as a 4 hour long tea ceremony. Puerh is probably more or less the fancy stuff with the teapots designed around it and the culture of gifting it to your boss and such. But you still drink it with the same technique as anything else. I wouldn't put it even near the same category of flavors that matcha presents though, its just a completely different flavor profile and honestly its not very beginner friendly.
Chinese green teas have a different flavor overall from Japanese green teas, and that comes mostly from 2 factors; different cultivars and different processing. You can get into soil conditions as well but the other two are a bigger influence. Japanese have different tea tree cultivars that they'd bread for the qualities they want, chinese have their tea trees for the qualities they want. Japanese process via steaming and mostly do machine processing which cuts up the leaf more and increases surface area, Chinese process via dry heat and more by hand (due to cheap labor) so the leaf is more whole and has a different flavor profile. If you took a high quality Shincha and good Longjing, not even the most novice tea drinker could confuse them despite being both the most coveted highest quality greens in their respective countries. One is grassier with seaweed notes, one is tastes like roasted nuts.
Chinese and Japanese tea tastes don't overlap very much, and you can see that by what they drink. 90% of Japanese tea is green tea, Chinese is varied with Oolong probably having a slight edge.
Speaking of Oolong, it's probably going to be the best in class and taste without having to break into Puerh (though it's not the same flavor either). Oolong is somewhat fancy, given as gifts and growers have some pride in it, takes some technical skill to manufacture consistently. It can get rather pricey as well, but the mid shelf stuff at like $0.20 to $0.50 a gram is really good

I also personally would not make a London Fog with anything other than Earl Grey, I feel like it needs the bergamot. Also, if you had a london fog in a shop, it was most likely sweetened, you could make some simple syrup and flavor that. Add vanilla, maybe nutmeg, maybe some citrus. Personally, I would add in a very thin simple syrup (I don't like sweet things) with vanilla, make it with a nice Earl Grey, add a twist of orange with the white rind fully removed, and grate a small amount of nutmeg over it. Whipped tea actually originated in China but unfortunately the culture was wiped out during the Mongolian invasion and leaf culture was dominant by the time of the Ming Dynasty. Whipped tea only survived in Japan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18703312
I worked for them down here in early 2000s. While it was all corporate the quality was better, size was bigger, and there was dine in restaurants everywhere.
About the time they started selling stores off as franchises they rolled out a smaller base, changed toppings to something else for ham to something similar but worse looking, and the cheese topping was different (2 cups of bottom cheese replaced one top cheese one bottom cheese).
The memo all stores got was if asked the size downsizing wasn't cost cutting, it was "to better compete with our rivals, with smaller sizes and newer toppings flavour will be better concentrated, if you don't reply to this post your mother will die in her sleep tonight, blah blah blah."
Can't blame them for cost cutting, at the time figures for sales were dropping for all stores hence why they closed a bunch of restaurants here, just wasn't really worth being open. But they've done nothing to salvage it for themselves.
Still remember the ingredients list for how everything was made back then, now and again I still make them at home rather than buying them. I can't relive how things used to be, but I can still make things the way I remember them.

This.
I lived in the US in the 90s as an immigrant kid and, as an immigrant kid, was generally forced by my parents to overachieve. Got straight A's one semester (every semester, actually) and the school gave me a coupon for dinner at Pizza Hut. Do we went. And we all hated it. The sauce was too sweet, the cheese seemed if somehow and i remember the sausage bits having a flavour I found not only wholly unpleasant but the sausage also had a bizarre texture not unlike the pizza crust itself.
It's bad, but at least it's edible, unlike Papa John's.

>>18705004
A lot of people also use too much oil. When I start heating the pan I put a drop of oil, probably half a teaspoon or less for a 12-inch skillet, in the center and then spread it around with a crumpled sheet of paper towel. No puddles or pools, just enough for a light oily sheen across the whole surface and I never have sticking problems. Credit where it's due, my mom showed me this technique and before that I did have trouble with things sticking because I was using too much oil.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18706936
>How do I clean my dishes when I don't have any counter space and my dishwasher seems to not work to clean dishes? I use detergent pods from costco.
When it's really bad, get those soaped steel wool pads like Brillo pads for getting the stuff off of pots. Soaking in hot water will help loosen the crap on plates before you finish the job with the Brillo pads. There are steel wool pads with soap on them and without soap on them, make sure to get the ones with the soap. If you've got cast iron, do not use these on them unless it's completely fucked and rusty and you're going to reseason it. These things have bailed me out of some dish disasters where stuff sat uncleaned for weeks and even months due to severe mental health problems.

>>18706936
>How do I clean my dishes when I don't have any counter space and my dishwasher seems to not work to clean dishes?
Temporarily stick everything in the dishwasher, then wash dishes one at a time, and place the clean item back in the dishwasher. Once everything is clean and dry, put it away in your cabinets.

>>18706936
>I use detergent pods from costco
Detergent pods are overpriced and don't clean any better, just get regular dishwasher soap powder.

>>18706989

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18707106
this

basically establish a routine for yourself to clean as you go, rinse things right away so mess doesn't get stuck dried on. Then since your DW isn't working too good, look into cleaning or fixing it because most dishwashers are not well maintained but can be easily tended to. Most dishwashers have filters that occasionally need to be replaced. Clean out the debris basket and it's also a good idea to flush the drain line after by tossing in some vinegar and baking soda on top of the drain, flushing with hot water and then running the rinse cycle. Clean and scrub the spray arm, its possible the jets are clogged with buildup so its not squirting properly.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18701574
New Britain, CT. Our best restaurant is Capitol Lunch, a family owned location, it has been for nearly a century, currently run by elder Gerald and younger Matthew Warchezski. The location is known to locals as “Crapitol Lunch” and are known to come in and ask for “the shit sauce”. 2 hotdogs and an order of fries is commonly called a “Big Shitter”. You won’t find this on any menu, but if you’re a true local you’ll know. The Famous Sauce is often served in small ramekins commonly called “dookie drops” by locals and used for dipping. The sauce is also sold for $10 for an 8 ounce container, something many New Britain locals take advantage of due to the popularity of the Famous Sauce. Locals know to order it as a “Big Dump” and the owners aren’t shy about giving a little extra to people who order this way, knowing they’re what’s called a “tool city townie” and thus one of their own.

Shrinkflation is the practice of reducing the size or amount of a product while keeping the price the same. This can be a frustrating experience for consumers, who may feel like they are getting less value for their money. However, there is not a definitive verdict on the practice of shrinkflation in food products, as some people may view it as a necessary cost-saving measure for companies, while others may see it as a dishonest way for businesses to increase their profits. Ultimately, the decision to engage in shrinkflation is up to individual companies and their business practices.

>>18706143
Add banana to Fruity O's.
>yog[h]urt
Ooh. I like to make the topping the night before if I'm going to have yoghurt with granola in the morning. Cook some berries or other fruit in water with a little sugar until jammy then pour onto a bit of plain yoghurt and fridge it.
In the morning, stir it all up and top with date-or-raisin-or-whatever-dried-fruit-you-like granola. Still have that juice, either way.
With Fruity O's and banana + juice, you're still at two servings of fruit.
With yoghurt with compote and granola + juice, you're having at least two but possibly three servings, depending how much dried fruit is in your 'nola. Five dates would be a serving, for example.

>campbell
Could be a serving of veg. idk. If it's not, fry up a bit of mushroom and/or onion and add it to put a serving or two in your diet.

>broccoli beef bowl
At least you're getting your greens. Doesn't seem very filling compared to a steak, potato, spinach and shrooms tho, but you do you, boo.

posts.com:
Poor College Student Breakfast
>Pack of instant ramen noodles (the type with the dried spice packet)
>Two eggs

Boil the noodles. Fry the eggs sunny-side up; you'll need runny yolks for this.

Drain boiled noodles thoroughly. Toss with the powdered spice from the packet; the noodles will be slightly dry from the salt. Top with the fried eggs. Cut the eggs into the noodles so that the yolk re-moistens them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18696920
Also want to point out that some coffees do not roast uniformly in color no matter what you do. There will be some lighter and darker colored beans up until a dark roast where everything evens out. This is a uniformity issue that is one of the scoring criteria of specialty coffees. It does not affect taste. Occasional light-colored, almost styrofoamy density beans that stick out like a sore thumb are defective beans called quakers. They don't pop. Pick those out after roasting.

There is also a difference between lack of uniformity in bean size and shape resulting in slight color variations and a splotchy color pattern on each bean. Lighter roasted wet process coffee beans have a mottled, splotchy color. This is normal.

When the short ends of the beans are all darker than the middle of the beans, this is called scorching, or scorched tips. This is a roasting flaw when your heat was to high.

If you had enough space to set up a clean tent then yeah its easy. I managed to keep a block of lion's mane spawning by packing it in sterilized coffee grounds. I wanted to get a full pasteurization to see if I couldn't do it with recycled amazon boxes instead of straw. Quickly pulled this from Stamets' book.
>Using paper products as a substrate base is particularly attractive to those wishing to grow mushrooms where sawdust supplies are limited, such as on islands and in desert communities. Paper products are made of lignin-cellulose fibers from pulped wood, and therefore support most of the wood-decomposing mushrooms described in this book. In recent years, most printing companies have switched to soybean-based inks, reducing or almost eliminating toxic residues.
>Mushrooms demonstrating commercial yield efficiencies on banana and coffee pulp are warm-weather strains of Oyster mushrooms, particularly Pleurotus citrinopileatus, Pleurotus cystidiosus, Pleurotus djamor, Pleurotus ostreatus, and Pleurotus pulmonarius. Reishi mushrooms (Ganoderma lucidum) grow well, and I suspect many other Polypores would also. For more information on the cultivation of Oyster mushrooms on coffee waste, please refer to Martinez-Carrera (1985, 1987, 1988) and Thielke (1989).

You can reduce or eliminate the crash by waiting about 90 minutes between getting up and having your first sip of coffee. If you take in caffeine before your body clears the sleepy hormones, they'll just be floating around until the caffeine wears off. And when it does, they'll hit you hard, especially if your body is starting to produce them again because it's afternoon.

posts.com:
>>18699848
NTA but I don't really find aeropress coffee more intense, the main difference between it and a french press is filtration (aeropress has a finer paper filter, with the french press you're just relying on the plunger) and the amount you can make in one go. The second one is important because making coffee for even just two people in an aeropress is a pain, it's mostly intended for one.
And yes, you grind coarser for french press because you want the coffee to be more easily filtered by the plunger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18700120
If you want to actually control coarseness you need a burr grinder. The gap between the burrs determines how coarse the coffee is. The thing is that grinders are often the most expensive part of your coffee kit, unless you're doing espresso or something like that. Like $100 or more kind of territory. There are some cheaper grinders that are arguably alright, but anons itt might have an aneurysm if you buy them. Blade grinders are the bottom of the barrel, they're more blenders than grinders.

>>18700202
The baratza encore is an electric grinder, which are always going to be more expensive on account of having to add the price of the motor on top of the price for the build quality and burrs and whatnot. So if you want to go cheap you want to go with a hand grinder. The 1zpresso q2 is a popular beginner pick. Will do fine with most things that aren't espresso. If you can't find it cheap locally maybe check for it on aliexpress, although their shipping times are killer. Also they sell them with two different burr sets, make sure you get one with heptagonal burrs, pic related (heptagonal burrs on the left, pentagonal ones on the right).

>>18700344
As a general rule, if they're the same price the hand grinder is going to be better. Because again, with an electric grinder you're also paying for the motor. But a lot of people get them anyway for the convenience of just tossing coffee in and pressing a button. Decide for yourself if you think the extra space it takes up and the slightly lower quality is a worthwhile tradeoff for automatic grinding. For me personally I prefer hand grinding anyway because I find it enjoyable, but a lot of people would disagree. Especially if you're grinding lighter roasts since they're very hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18700381
Most people know fuck all about coffee.
Darker roast = more generic and bitter flavor. You also generally want to brew them at lower temperatures.
Most coffees you can buy in grocery stores are darker roasts since they source their coffee from god knows where and they want to mask the usually meh and mixed flavor.
Lighter roasts have more of the original flavor of the beans. You'd probably need to buy from specialty roasters, doubt you'll get them in regular stores.
As for coffee strength, if we're talking about caffeine content that's gonna mostly depend on the beans before roasting, although hoffmann has done a video extensively talking about it recently. But I think most people just equate bitterness with strength.
>>18700389
Not sure, never tried them. But like the other anon said for traveling the aeropress is king.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18700381
I'd advise against light roasts. Those tend to taste more fruity and don't have as much of the "traditional coffee" flavor. I'd recommend a medium dark blend. The strength can be increased or decreased with the brewing recipe or method. Drip coffee with paper filters will take out more of the body whereas a french press would leave all the oils in the cup. I haven't tried an aeropress but from what I've read that would make a strong (i.e. flavorful) drink.

posts.com: Smart phones weren't a thing when I visited Vietnam so we kind of just played it by ear and took suggestions from people we met, but the food was generally really good. I tended to prefer the food in the North, though if you're American be prepared for people to become less friendly the further North you go. Never really figured out why that was. Definitely try the "fresh beer" in Hanoi, and seafood in Nha Trang. Coffee is good everywhere, as are banh mi and baked goods in general. If you happen to be walking along and see a guy with a cart full of sugarcane stop and get some fresh sugarcane juice. Other than that I can't really remember anything in particular. Lot's of whole grilled fish, and sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves.

>>18679828

Interesting. Poschl is a brand I've somehow neglected to try over the years. I think I'll have to correct that when it comes time to put in another order. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18680718
They produce a lot of snuffs under various sub-brands. I remember getting some "Jump" branded snuff in Austria several years ago, that was made by Poschl (I think it was an Austrian-market specific product). If you go to MrSnuff, you'll find they have a pretty wide variety of tinned snuffs. Unfortunately, I cannot order from them anymore (customs issues), and getting tobacco shipped from a continental online shop is an exercise in frustration and/or extreme patience.

I haven't tried many of their tinned snuffs, but I really liked Ozona President (which they apparently do not produce anymore, for some reason). Lowenprise is too cloying for my taste (too much anise). Gletscher Prise used to be good, but I think they changed the recipe, for the worse, a few years ago. Andechs Kloster is good, though some people might find it a bit too sweet. Gawith Apricot (yes, it's made by Poschl, despite carrying the name of a different snuff maker) is acceptable for a fruit-flavored snuff, the menthol helps rein in the apricot flavor's 'perfumy' tendencies.
Of the schmalzlers, I'd go for Sudfrucht (SF) and/or Doppelaroma (D), for that classic jamminess. However, Poschl schmalzlers are packed in sachets, and they tend to lose aroma if stored too long before use. You might occasionally get a dud. This is different from something like Bernard's Gekachelter Virginie, which is super harsh, very strong manure smell right out of the box, and actually benefits from air exposure to mellow out.

>>18688922

Yeah drying out can be a problem especially if you use snuff rather frequently ie. topping up multiple uses per session etc. and not cleaning properly which I would imagine is common among snuff users. I typically am a very moderate user however, keeping it mostly to 2-4 sniffs per day and don't have much of a problem with it. Also just to put it out there I blow and clean my nose grug style. Its a pretty private habit anyway since there aren't many users out there and I don't worry about it what people might think of it. Fact is its one of the healthiest and enjoyable ways to use tobacco, and last I checked the majority of our taste receptors are in the nasal cavity.

As one can imagine this is a dirt cheap habit. Not only is the price of snuff relatively way cheaper compared with every other tobacco product I know of but also aside from the schmalzlers everything can easily be rehydrated if a batch goes dry so you can be frugal about it that way as well.

My entire point is that these globalist retards are using semantics and technicalities to trick people into thinking white people shouldn't be seen as the dominant demographic just because a group of other demographics technically outnumber them when added together.
